$p^{F}$ which is generally different from 1 in $\operatorname{End}\left(M(Y)^{F}\right)$. The other two arrows are ring homomorphisms.

Recall that two $F$-varieties $X_{1}$ and $X_{2}$ are equivalent $(\bmod p)$ if there exist correspondences $X_{1} \rightsquigarrow X_{2}$ and $X_{2} \rightsquigarrow X_{1}$ both with multiplicity $1 \in \mathbb{F}$, see $[6, \S 2]$. We now prove that, under some conditions on $Y$, the A-upper motives of $X$ are classified by some Artin motives, namely the indecomposable summands of $M(L)^{F}$.

Theorem 5.6. Let $X=Y^{F}$ be the corestriction of a projective homogeneous variety $Y$ under a reductive algebraic group, defined over a finite separable field extension $L / F$. We assume that either $L / F$ is Galois, or the degree of its normal closure is prime to $p$.
(a) All nontrivial indecomposable summands of $U(Y)^{F}$ have nontrivial image under $\mathbf{m}$, and hence are $A$-upper motives of $X$.
(b) Assume in addition that there exists a projective homogeneous variety $\hat{Y}$ under a reductive algebraic group, defined over $F$, and such that $\hat{Y}_{L}$ is equivalent to $Y \bmod p$. Then the following holds:
(1) every summand in $M(L)^{F}$ is isomorphic to the image under $\mathbf{m}$ of a summand in $U(Y)^{F}$
(2) two summands in $U(Y)^{F}$ with isomorphic images under $\mathbf{m}$ are isomorphic;
(3) a summand in $U(Y)^{F}$ is indecomposable if and only if its image under $\mathbf{m}$ is so.

Notation 5.7. Under the hypothesis of Theorem 5.6 (b), any indecomposable summand $A$ of $M(L)^{F}$ corresponds to an A-upper motive of $X=Y^{F}$. It is uniquely defined up to isomorphism, and will be denoted by $U_{A}(Y)$. Note that the base field $F$ of the motive $U_{A}(Y)$ does not show up in this notation because it is concealed in the motive $A$.

With this notation in hand, Theorem 5.6 (b) implies that, under its hypothesis, given a complete decomposition $M(L)^{F}=A_{1} \oplus \cdots \oplus A_{r}$, we get a complete decomposition $U(Y)^{F}=U_{A_{1}}(Y) \oplus \cdots \oplus U_{A_{r}}(Y)$, and the summands $U_{A_{i}}(Y)$ are the A-upper motives of $X=Y^{F}$.

The rest of the section is devoted to the proof of Theorem 5.6.
Proof of Theorem 5.6 in the Galois case. We assume that $L / F$ is Galois and we write $\Gamma$ for its Galois group $\Gamma=\Gamma_{F} / \Gamma_{L}$.

Let us first prove (a). By (4.5) we have

$$
\left(Y^{F}\right)_{L}=\coprod_{\sigma \in \Gamma} Y_{\sigma}
$$

We claim that

$$
\left(U(Y)^{F}\right)_{L} \stackrel{\simeq}{\bigoplus} U(Y)_{\sigma}=\bigoplus_{\sigma \in \Gamma} U\left(Y_{\sigma}\right)
$$

Indeed, consider a complete decomposition $M(Y)=U(Y) \oplus Q_{1} \cdots \oplus Q_{r}$ of $M(Y)$. By definition of the upper motive, we have $\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(Q_{i}\right)=0$ for $1 \leq i \leq r$, hence $\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(Q_{i}^{F}\right)=0=$ $\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(\left(Q_{i}^{F}\right)_{L}\right)$, see $[12, \S 3]$. It follows that $\bigoplus_{\sigma \in \Gamma} U\left(Y_{\sigma}\right)$ is a summand of $\left(U(Y)^{F}\right)_{L}$. Over $\bar{F}$, both are isomorphic to $[L: F]$ copies of $\overline{U(Y)}$, and by the nilpotence principle, this proves $(5.8)$.

Let us now consider a nontrivial projector $p \in \operatorname{End}\left(U(Y)^{F}\right)$, defining a direct summand $M$ of $U(Y)^{F}$. We need to prove that its image $\mathbf{m}(p)=q \in \operatorname{End}\left(M(L)^{F}\right)$ is nontrivial. The Krull-Schmidt property shows that $M_{L}=\bigoplus_{\sigma \in S} U\left(Y_{\sigma}\right)$ for some nonempty subset $S$ of $\Gamma$. By Lemma 4.4, $\mathbf{m}\left(U\left(Y_{\sigma}\right)\right)$ is the copy of $M(L)$ indexed by $\sigma$ in

$$
\mathbf{m}\left(M\left(Y^{F}\right)_{L}\right)=\bigoplus_{\sigma \in \Gamma} M(L)
$$

Therefore, $\mathbf{m}(M)$ is nontrivial, as required.
To prove (b), we use the following:
Lemma 5.9. The ring homomorphism

$$
\mathbf{m}: \operatorname{End}\left(U(Y)^{F}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{End}\left(M(L)^{F}\right)
$$

given by the functor $\mathbf{m}$ is surjective; its kernel consists of nilpotents.
Proof. The second assertion follows from (a): consider $f \in \operatorname{End}\left(U(Y)^{F}\right)$ and assume $\mathbf{m}(f)=0$. Since we work with finite coefficients, by [14, Corollary 2.2], some power of $f$ is a projector $q$, which satisfies $\mathbf{m}(q)=0$. Therefore (a) asserts $q=0$, and this shows $f$ is nilpotent.

Let us assume now that there exists a variety $\hat{Y}$ as in the statement of Theorem 5.6 (b). Since $Y$, hence also $Y_{\sigma}$, is equivalent to $\hat{Y}_{L}$ for any $\sigma \in \Gamma$, there exists a multiplicity 1 correspondence $Y_{\sigma} \rightsquigarrow Y$. As explained in Lemma 4.4, we may view it as an element of $\operatorname{End}\left(M(Y)^{F}\right)$, and it maps under $\mathbf{m}$ to $\sigma \in \mathbb{F}[\Gamma]$. This proves that $\operatorname{End}\left(M(Y)^{F}\right)$ maps surjectively onto $\operatorname{End}\left(M(L)^{F}\right)=\mathbb{F}[\Gamma]$. Lemma 5.9 follows by diagram (5.5).

With this in hand, assertions (1), (2) and (3), in the Galois case, are proved as follows.
(1) By Lemma 5.9, the projector $p$ defining a given summand in $M(L)^{F}$ lifts to an element of $\operatorname{End}\left(U(Y)^{F}\right)$. By [14, Corollary 2.2], an appropriate power of this element is a projector which maps to $p$ under $\mathbf{m}$.
(2) Let $M_{1}$ and $M_{2}$ be summands of $U(Y)^{F}$. Any morphism between $\mathbf{m}\left(M_{1}\right)$ and $\mathbf{m}\left(M_{2}\right)$ is given by an endomorphism of $M(L)^{F}$ and therefore, by Lemma 5.9, can be lifted to a morphism between $M_{1}$ and $M_{2}$. In particular, if $\mathbf{m}\left(M_{1}\right)$ and $\mathbf{m}\left(M_{2}\right)$ are isomorphic, mutually inverse isomorphisms lift to some morphisms $f: M_{1} \rightarrow M_{2}$ and $g: M_{2} \rightarrow M_{1}$. By Lemma 5.9 once again, each of the compositions $g \circ f$ and $f \circ g$ has the form id $+\varepsilon$ with some nilpotent $\varepsilon$ and so is an isomorphism (with inverse given by the finite sum id $-\varepsilon+\varepsilon^{2}-\ldots$ ). It follows that $f$ and $g$ are isomorphisms, even though they need not be mutually inverse.
(3) This is a consequence of (1) and (2), since the functor $\mathbf{m}$ preserves direct sum decompositions.

Proof of Theorem 5.6 in the non-Galois case. We first prove the following result, which is of independent interest, and will be used in the proof:

Lemma 5.10. Let $Z / F$ be a projective homogeneous variety under the action of a reductive group. Let $L / F$ be a finite separable field extension, and assume that $[E: F]$ is prime to $p$, where $E$ is a normal closure of $L / F$. Then then restriction $U(Z)_{L}$ of the upper motive of $Z$ is isomorphic to $U\left(Z_{L}\right)$. In particular, it is indecomposable.

Proof. Since $U(Z)_{L}$ is an upper summand in $M\left(Z_{L}\right)$, it contains $U\left(Z_{L}\right)$ as a direct summand; therefore, they are isomorphic if and only if $U(Z)_{L}$ is indecomposable. So, it is enough to prove that $U(Z)_{E}$ is indecomposable, or equivalently, isomorphic to $U\left(Z_{E}\right)$. Hence, we may assume that $L / F$ is Galois and $[L: F]$ is prime to $p$. Consider the variety $Y=Z_{L}$. The varieties $Y^{F}$ and $Z$ are equivalent $(\bmod p)$ by Remark 2.1, so Corollary 2.15 in [14] shows that $U\left(Y^{F}\right) \simeq U(Z)$. Hence, we may view $U(Z)$ as a direct summand of $U(Y)^{F}$, and $U(Z)_{L}$ as a direct summand of $\left(U(Y)^{F}\right)_{L}$. Since $Y=Z_{L}$, we have $Y_{\sigma} \simeq Y$ for all $\sigma$ in the Galois group of $L / F$. It follows by (5.8) that $U(Z)_{L}$ is isomorphic to a direct sum of copies of $U\left(Z_{L}\right)$. Since $\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(U(Z)_{L}\right)=\mathbb{F}=\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(U\left(Z_{L}\right)\right)$, we get $U(Z)_{L}=U\left(Z_{L}\right)$ as expected.

We may now prove part (a) of Theorem 5.6. We continue to assume that the degree of normal closure of $L / F$ is prime to $p$. Let $M$ be a nontrivial summand of $U(Y)^{F}$, and consider its restriction $M_{E}$, which also is nontrivial by the nilpotence principle. Since $E$ is the normal closure of $L / F, \gamma(L) \subset E$ for all $\gamma \in \Gamma_{F}$, and we have $L \otimes_{F} E=\prod_{\Gamma_{F} / \Gamma_{L}} E$, as in (3.2). Therefore, the same computations as in the Galois case show that

$$
\left(U(Y)^{F}\right)_{E} \simeq \bigoplus_{\gamma \Gamma_{L} \in \Gamma_{F} / \Gamma_{L}}\left(U(Y)_{E}\right)_{\gamma}
$$

where $\left(U(Y)_{E}\right)_{\gamma}$ does not depend on the choice of $\gamma$ in its class, since $Y$ is defined over L. By Lemma 5.10, $U(Y)_{E}=U\left(Y_{E}\right)$ is indecomposable, and so are the $\left(U(Y)_{E}\right)_{\gamma}=$ $U\left(\left(Y_{E}\right)_{\gamma}\right)$. It follows that $M_{E}$, which is a direct sum of some of these upper motives, has non-zero image under the functor $\mathbf{m}$, as required.

To prove part (b) of Theorem 5.6, consider a projective homogeneous variety $\hat{Y}$ over $F$ such that $Y$ is equivalent to $(\hat{Y})_{L}$ as in the statement. Applying again Remark 2.1 and [14, Cor. 2.15], we get that $\hat{Y}$ is equivalent to $Y^{F}$, and $U(\hat{Y}) \simeq U\left(Y^{F}\right)$. It follows that $U\left(Y^{F}\right)_{L} \simeq U(\hat{Y})_{L}$. Applying Lemma 5.10 to $\hat{Y}$, we get:

$$
U\left(Y^{F}\right)_{L} \simeq U\left(\hat{Y}_{L}\right) \simeq U(Y)
$$

Using this, we now prove that the corestriction of the upper motive of $Y$ satisfies

$$
U(Y)^{F} \simeq U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes M(L)^{F}
$$

Indeed, since $U(Y)$ is an $L$-motive, we have $U(Y) \simeq U(Y) \otimes M(L)$. Taking the corestriction and using (5.11), we get

$$
U(Y)^{F} \simeq\left(U\left(Y^{F}\right)_{L} \otimes M(L)\right)^{F} \simeq U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes M(L)^{F}
$$

where the second isomorphism is a particular case of the general formula $\left(M_{L} \otimes N\right)^{F}=$ $M \otimes N^{F}$, which holds for any $F$-motive $M$ and $L$-motive $N$, with $L / F$ finite and separable.

Hence, any direct summand $A$ in $M(L)^{F}$ produces a direct summand $U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A$ in $U(Y)^{F}$. It satisfies $\mathbf{m}\left(U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A\right)=\mathbb{F} \otimes A=A$, see Example 5.2 and Remark 4.8. To finish the proof, we will use the following:

Lemma 5.13. We continue to assume that the degree of normal closure of $L / F$ is prime to p. Under the hypothesis of Theorem 5.6 (b), the motive $M=U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A$ is indecomposable for any indecomposable summand $A$ of $M(L)^{F}$.

Assuming the lemma, we get that a complete decomposition $M(L)^{F}=A_{1} \oplus \cdots \oplus A_{k}$ of the spectrum of $L$ yields a complete decomposition

$$
U(Y)^{F} \simeq U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes M(L)^{F} \simeq \bigoplus_{i=A}^{k}\left(U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A_{i}\right)
$$

Assertions (1), (2) and (3) of the theorem follows immediately. So, it only remains to prove Lemma 5.13. For this, we consider motivic decompositions of $U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A$ over various extensions of the base field $F$.

First, observe that the motive $A_{E}$, which is a direct summand of the motive of $L \otimes_{F} E$ is a direct sum of $\operatorname{rk}(A)$ copies of the Tate motive $\mathbb{F}=M(E)$, where $\operatorname{rk}(A)$ is the rank of $A$. Since in addition $U\left(Y^{F}\right)_{E}$ is indecomposable by Lemma 5.10, we get that $\left(U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A\right)_{E}$ is a direct sum of $r$ copies of the indecomposable motive $U\left(Y^{F}\right)_{E}$.

On the other hand, the variety $\hat{Y}$ is a projective homogeneous variety under the action of a reductive group $G$ defined over $F$. Let $X_{G}$ be the $F$-variety of Borel subgroups of $G$. Over $F\left(X_{G}\right)$, the group $G$ is quasi-split, so $U\left(Y^{F}\right)_{F\left(X_{G}\right)}=U(\hat{Y})_{F\left(X_{G}\right)}$ is a direct sum of a Tate motive $\mathbb{F}=M\left(F\left(X_{G}\right)\right)$ and some positive shifts of some effective motives. Hence, $\left(U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A\right)_{F\left(X_{G}\right)}$ decomposes as a direct sum of the motive $A_{F\left(X_{G}\right)}$ and a motive $B$ with $\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(B_{K}\right)=0$ for all field extensions $K / F\left(X_{G}\right)$. By Corollary 3.8, we know in addition that $A_{F\left(X_{G}\right)}$ is indecomposable.

Using these observations, let us now prove Lemma 5.13. Consider a nontrivial direct summand $U$ in $U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A$. Over $E, U_{E}$ is a direct sum of $s$ copies of $U\left(Y^{F}\right)_{E}$, for some $s$ with $1 \leq s \leq \operatorname{rk}(A)$, which also is the dimension over $\mathbb{F}$ of $\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(U_{E}\right)$. Therefore, $\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(U_{E\left(X_{G}\right)}\right)$ is non zero, and this implies that $A_{F\left(X_{G}\right)}$ is a direct summand of $U_{F\left(X_{G}\right)}$. It follows that

$$
s \geq \operatorname{dim} \operatorname{Ch}^{0}\left(A_{E\left(X_{G}\right)}\right)=\operatorname{rk}(A)
$$

So $U_{E}$ is a direct sum of $\operatorname{rk}(A)$ copies of $U\left(Y^{F}\right)_{E}$ and by the nilpotence principle, this implies $U=U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A$. This proves that $U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A$ is indecomposable.

Remark 5.14. We continue to assume that the degree of normal closure of $L / F$ is prime to $p$. From the above proof, we get that under the assumptions of Theorem 5.6 (b), we have

$$
U_{A}(Y) \simeq U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A
$$

for any indecomposable summand $A$ in $M(L)^{F}$, where $U_{A}(Y)$ is as in Notation 5.7. Moreover, for any field extension $K / F$ such that $Y_{K}$ is irreducible and $A_{K}$ is indecomposable, we claim that the $K$-motive $\left(U_{A}(Y)\right)_{K}$ contains a summand isomorphic to $A_{K}$ if and only if $\left(U\left(Y^{F}\right)\right)_{K}$ contains a Tate motive $\mathbb{F}$. One implication follows immediately from (5.15);

to prove the converse, note that the indecomposable summands of $\left(U_{A}(Y)\right)_{K}$ are isomorphic to $P \otimes A_{K}$, where $P$ describes indecomposable summands of $U\left(Y^{F}\right)_{K}$. Comparing the ranks, if such a summand $P \otimes A_{K}$ is isomorphic to $A_{K}$, then $P$ has rank 1. By [14, Lemma 2.21], it follows that $\left(Y^{F}\right)_{K}$ has a 0 -cycle of degree $1 \in \mathbb{F}$. So its upper motive, which is a summand of $U\left(Y^{F}\right)_{K}$, contains a summand isomorphic to $\mathbb{F}$ and this proves the claim.

# 6. Motivic decompositions 

Let $G$ be a reductive group defined over $F$. If $G$ is of inner type, indecomposable summands of a complete motivic decomposition of any projective $G$-homogeneous $F$ variety are described in [14, Theorem 3.5]. A generalization of this result dealing with groups of $p$-inner type, that is groups which become of inner type over a $p$-power field extension of $F$, is given in [12, Theorem 1.1]. In both cases, the description is in terms of upper motives of some projective homogeneous varieties. The main result of this section is Theorem 6.3, which provides another generalization of [14, Theorem 3.5] in a different direction. It uses the notion of A-upper motives of $G$, defined as follows:

Definition 6.1. Let $G$ be a reductive group over $F$ and let $E / F$ be a minimal field extension such that $G_{E}$ is of inner type. An $A$-upper motive of $G$ is an $F$-motive isomorphic to an A-upper motive of $Y^{F}$ for some projective $G_{L}$-homogeneous variety $Y$, defined over an intermediate field $L$ of $E / F$.

Remark 6.2. Note that for a given $G$, the field extension $E / F$ in Definition 6.1 is uniquely determined up to $F$-isomorphism so that its choice does not influence the notion of A-upper motives of $G$.

The group $G$ is called $p^{\prime}$-inner if the degree of $E / F$ is prime to $p$.
Theorem 6.3. Let $G$ be a $p^{\prime}$-inner reductive group defined over $F$. Every summand in the complete decomposition of the Chow motive with coefficients in $\mathbb{F}=\mathbb{Z} / p \mathbb{Z}$ of any projective $G$-homogeneous variety $X$ is a Tate shift of an $A$-upper motive of $G$.

Proof. Since the center of $G$ acts on $X$ trivially, we may assume that $G$ is semisimple and adjoint.

We write $D_{G}$ (or simply $D$ ) for the set of vertices of the Dynkin diagram of $G$, and let $E / F$ be a minimal field extension with inner $G_{E}$. The field extension $E / F$ is Galois and its Galois group $\Gamma=\operatorname{Gal}(E / F)$ acts on $D$. For a field $L$ with $F \subset L \subset E$, the set $D_{G_{L}}$ is identified with $D=D_{G}$. Any $\operatorname{Gal}(E / L)$-stable subset $\tau$ in $D$ determines a projective $G_{L}$-homogeneous variety $Y_{G_{L}, \tau}$ the way described in $[14, \S 3]$ (which is opposite to the original convention of $[20, \S 1.6])$. For instance, $Y_{G_{L}, D}$ is the variety of Borel subgroups of $G_{L}$, and $Y_{G_{L}, \emptyset}=\operatorname{Spec} L$. Any projective $G_{L}$-homogeneous variety is isomorphic to $Y_{G_{L}, \tau}$ for some $\operatorname{Gal}(E / L)$-stable $\tau \subset D$.

We prove Theorem 6.3 simultaneously for all $F, G, X$ using induction on $n:=\operatorname{dim} X$. The base of the induction is $n=0$ where $X=\operatorname{Spec} F$ and the statement is trivial.

From now on we are assuming that $n \geq 1$ and that Theorem 6.3 is already proven for varieties of dimension $<n$.

For any field extension $L / F$, we write $\tilde{L}$ for the function field $L(X)$ (note that any projective homogeneous variety and, in particular $X$, is geometrically integral). Let $G^{\prime}$ be the semisimple group over the field $\tilde{F}=F(X)$ given by the semisimple anisotropic kernel of the group $G_{\tilde{F}}$. We note that the group $G_{\tilde{E}}^{\prime}$ is of inner type. By Lemma 3.7, the field extension $\tilde{E} / \tilde{F}$ is Galois with Galois group

$$
\Gamma=\operatorname{Gal}(\tilde{E} / \tilde{F})=\operatorname{Gal}(E / F)
$$

In particular, any of its intermediate fields is of the form $\tilde{L}$ for some intermediate field $L$ of the extension $E / F$. The set $D_{G^{\prime}}$ is identified with a $\Gamma$-invariant subset in $D_{G}$; the complement $D_{G} \backslash D_{G^{\prime}}$ contains the subset in $D_{G}$ corresponding to $X$.

Let $M$ be an indecomposable summand of the motive of $X$. We are going to show that $M$ is isomorphic to a shift of a direct summand in $U\left(Y_{G_{L}, \tau}\right)^{F}$ for some intermediate field $L$ of $E / F$ and some $\operatorname{Gal}(E / L)$-stable subset $\tau \subset D_{G}$ containing the complement of $D_{G^{\prime}}$. This will prove Theorem 6.3.

According to [1, Theorem 4.2] (an enhancement of [2, Theorem 7.5]), the motive of $X_{\tilde{F}}$ decomposes into a sum of shifts of motives of projective $G_{L}^{\prime}$-homogeneous varieties $Y$, satisfying $\operatorname{dim} Y<\operatorname{dim} X=n$, where $L$ runs over intermediate fields of the extension $E / F$ by Lemma 3.8. It follows by the induction hypothesis that each summand of the complete motivic decomposition of $X_{\tilde{F}}$ is a shift $N^{\prime}\{i\}$ of a summand $N^{\prime}$ in $U\left(Y^{\prime}\right)^{\tilde{F}}$ for some $L / F \subset E / F$, some $\operatorname{Gal}(E / L)$-stable $\tau^{\prime} \subset D_{G^{\prime}}$, and $Y^{\prime}:=Y_{G_{L, \tau^{\prime}}^{\prime}}$. By the KrullSchmidt property [12, Corollary 2.2], the summands of the complete decomposition of $M_{\tilde{F}}$ are also of this shape.

In the complete decomposition of $M_{\tilde{F}}$, let us choose a summand $N^{\prime}\{i\}$ with minimal $i$. It corresponds to a subset $\tau^{\prime} \subset D_{G^{\prime}}$, and we set $\tau:=\tau^{\prime} \cup\left(D_{G} \backslash D_{G^{\prime}}\right) \subset D_{G}$. The subset $\tau$ is $\operatorname{Gal}(E / L)$-stable. To prove Theorem 6.3, it is enough to show that $M$ is isomorphic to a direct summand in $U(Y)^{F}\{i\}$ for these $L, \tau, i$, and $Y:=Y_{G_{L}, \tau}$.

Since $M$ is indecomposable, it suffices to construct morphisms

$$
\alpha: U(Y)^{F}\{i\} \rightarrow M \text { and } \beta: M \rightarrow U(Y)^{F}\{i\}
$$

such that no power of the composition $\alpha \circ \beta$ vanishes. (We recall that by [14, Corollary 2.2], an appropriate power of any endomorphism of $M$ is a projector.)

We first construct certain, defined over the field $\tilde{F}$, predecessors $\tilde{\alpha}$ and $\tilde{\beta}$ of $\alpha$ and $\beta$. Recall that $N^{\prime}\{i\}$ is a summand in $M_{\tilde{F}}$ and in $U\left(Y^{\prime}\right)^{\tilde{F}}\{i\}$. Since $U\left(Y^{\prime}\right)=U\left(Y_{\tilde{L}}\right)$ by [14, Cor. 2.15], $U\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$ is a summand in $U(Y)_{\tilde{L}}$. Therefore, $U\left(Y^{\prime}\right)^{\tilde{F}}$ is a summand in

$$
\left(U(Y)_{\tilde{L}}\right)^{\tilde{F}}=\left(U(Y)^{F}\right)_{\tilde{F}}
$$

Using projections to and inclusions of direct summands, we define $\tilde{\alpha}$ and $\tilde{\beta}$ as the compositions

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tilde{\alpha}: U(Y)^{F}\{i\}_{\tilde{F}} \rightarrow U\left(Y^{\prime}\right)^{\tilde{F}}\{i\} \rightarrow N^{\prime}\{i\} & \hookrightarrow M_{\tilde{F}} \quad \text { and } \\
& \tilde{\beta}: M_{\tilde{F}} \rightarrow N^{\prime}\{i\} \hookrightarrow U\left(Y^{\prime}\right)^{\tilde{F}}\{i\} \hookrightarrow U(Y)^{F}\{i\}_{\tilde{F}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\rightarrow$ is a sign for a projection onto a direct summand and $\hookrightarrow$ means an inclusion of a direct summand. The composition $\tilde{\alpha} \circ \tilde{\beta}$ is the projector which yields the summand $N^{\prime}\{i\}$ of $M_{\tilde{F}}$.

Now we construct $\alpha$ and $\beta$ starting with $\alpha$. Note that $\tilde{\alpha}$ is an element of the Chow group $\operatorname{Ch}\left(Y^{F} \times X\right)_{\tilde{F}}$ over $\tilde{F}$. We take for $\alpha$ an element of the Chow group $\operatorname{Ch}\left(Y^{F} \times X\right)$ over $F$ such that its image under the surjective ring homomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Ch}\left(Y^{F} \times X\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ch}\left(X_{F\left(Y^{F}\right)}\right)
$$

(from [7, Corollary 57.11]) followed by the change of field homomorphism for the field extension $\tilde{F}\left(Y^{F}\right) / F\left(Y^{F}\right)$, coincides with the image of $\tilde{\alpha}$ under the surjective ring homomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Ch}\left(Y^{F} \times X\right)_{\tilde{F}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Ch}\left(X_{\tilde{F}\left(Y^{F}\right)}\right)
$$

Such $\alpha$ exists because the field extension $\tilde{F}\left(Y^{F}\right) / F\left(Y^{F}\right)$ is purely transcendental and therefore the change of field homomorphism $\operatorname{Ch}\left(X_{F\left(Y^{F}\right)}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ch}\left(X_{\tilde{F}\left(Y^{F}\right)}\right)$ is surjective as follows from the homotopy invariance of Chow groups (see [7, Theorem 57.13] or [7, Corollary 52.11]) and [7, Corollary 57.11]).

In order to define $\beta$, we note that $\tilde{\beta}$ is an element of $\operatorname{Ch}\left(X \times Y^{F}\right)_{\tilde{F}}$ and let $\beta^{\prime}$ be an element of $\operatorname{Ch}\left(X \times X \times Y^{F}\right)$ mapped to $\tilde{\beta}$ under the surjection (from [7, Corollary 57.11])

$$
\operatorname{Ch}\left(X \times X \times Y^{F}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ch}\left(X \times Y^{F}\right)_{\tilde{F}}
$$

given by the generic point of the second factor in the product $X \times X \times Y^{F}$. We consider $\beta^{\prime}$ as a correspondence $X \rightsquigarrow X \times Y^{F}$ and let $\beta^{\prime \prime}$ be the composition of correspondences $\beta^{\prime} \circ \mu$, where $\mu \in \operatorname{Ch}(X \times X)$ is the projector which yields the motivic summand $M$ of $X$. Finally, we define $\beta$ as the pullback of $\beta^{\prime \prime}$ with respect to the closed embedding

$$
X \times Y^{F} \hookrightarrow X \times X \times Y^{F}, \quad(x, y) \mapsto(x, x, y)
$$

given by the diagonal of $X$.
Composing with the relevant idempotents, the elements $\alpha$ and $\beta$ we constructed induce morphisms as in (6.4). Changing notation, we write below $\alpha$ and $\beta$ for these two morphisms. In particular, the composition $\alpha \circ \beta$ is an endomorphism of the motive $M$. By [14, Corollary 2.2], an appropriate power $(\alpha \circ \beta)^{\circ r}$ of this endomorphism is a projector which defines a summand in $M$. The morphisms $\beta$ and $\alpha \circ(\beta \circ \alpha)^{\circ(r-1)}$ identify this summand with a summand in $U(Y)^{F}\{i\}$ which we write in the form $N\{i\}$ for certain summand $N$ in $U(Y)^{F}$. By indecomposability of $M$, it suffices to check that $N \neq 0$ to conclude the proof.

Since $N^{\prime} \neq 0$, we have $\mathbf{m}\left(N^{\prime}\right) \neq 0$ by Theorem 5.6(a). In other terms, $\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(N_{\tilde{F}}^{\prime}\right) \neq 0$, where $\tilde{F}$ is a separable closure of the field $\tilde{F}$. So, the composition $\tilde{\alpha} \circ \tilde{\beta}$ yields a nonzero projector on $\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(Y^{F}\right)_{\tilde{F}}$. By the construction of $\alpha$ and $\beta$, the action of the composition $\alpha \circ \beta$ on $\mathrm{Ch}^{0}\left(Y^{F}\right)_{\tilde{F}}$ coincides with the action of $\tilde{\alpha} \circ \tilde{\beta}$ (cf. [14, Proof of Theorem 3.5]) and therefore also yields a nonzero projector. Consequently, $\mathbf{m}(N) \neq 0$ and it follows that $N$ is nonzero.

Remark 6.5. Instead of [1, Theorem 4.2], the weaker result [2, Theorem 7.5] can be used in the proof of Theorem 6.3. To do so, it suffices to take for $G^{\prime}$ the semisimple part of the parabolic subgroup defining $X_{\tilde{F}}$.

Remark 6.6. As follows from the proof of Theorem 6.3, the A-upper motives of $G$, whose Tate shifts actually appear as direct summands of $M(X)$ in Theorem 6.3, are associated with varieties $Y$ with $Y^{F}$ dominating $X$ in the sense of $[4, \S 2]$ (see also [6, Lemma 2.2]).

# 7. CLASSIFICATION RESULTS 

By [6, Thm. 4.3], using the Tate trace defined as a pure Tate summand of maximal rank of a motive, one may classify motives in a broad subcategory of the category of Chow motives $\mathrm{CM}(F, \mathbb{F})$, with as usual $\mathbb{F}=\mathbb{Z} / p \mathbb{Z}$. This subcategory contains motives of projective homogeneous varieties under the action of a reductive group of $p$-inner type (i.e. of inner type over a $p$-power extension of $F$ ). On the other hand, this theorem does not apply when the reductive group is not $p$-inner, see Remark 3.6 for an explicit counter-example using Artin motives.

The purpose of this section is to obtain a similar classification result in a different subcategory of $\mathrm{CM}(F, \mathbb{F})$, which contains projective homogeneous varieties under the action of some reductive groups which are $p^{\prime}$-inner, see $\S 6$ for a definition. A precise statement is given in Theorem 7.6 below. To achieve this, we need to replace the Tate trace by the Artin-Tate trace of a motive, defined as the part of a complete decomposition of this motive which consists of Artin-Tate motives, i.e. shifts of Artin motives.

We first establish a criterion of isomorphism for A-upper motives of some reductive groups, a crucial tool in the proof of Theorem 7.6. This can be done using Theorem 5.6(b), by slightly restricting the class of reductive groups we are working with.
Definition 7.1. Let $G$ be a reductive group, and let $E / F$ be a minimal Galois field extension over which $G$ is of inner type. The group $G$ is called $p$-consistent if for any intermediate field $L$ in $E / F$ and any projective homogeneous $G_{L}$-variety $Y$ over $L$, there exists a $G$-projective homogeneous variety $\bar{Y}$ over $F$ such that the $L$ varieties $\bar{Y}_{L}$ and $Y$ are equivalent $(\bmod p)$.

In particular, if $G$ is $p^{\prime}$-inner and $p$-consistent, the hypotheses of Theorem 5.6(b) apply to varieties $Y$ as in the definition, so we may use the notation $U_{A}(Y)$ introduced in 5.7 for its A-upper motives, where $A$ runs through indecomposable summands of the Artin motive $M(L)^{F}$.

Any non- $p$-inner absolutely simple group of type different from ${ }^{3} \mathcal{D}_{4}$ and ${ }^{6} \mathcal{D}_{4}$ is both $p^{\prime}$-inner and $p$-consistent (for instance, the 3 -consistency of $E_{6}$ follows from [5]). A direct product of $p^{\prime}$-inner $p$-consistent groups is $p^{\prime}$-inner and $p$-consistent. Here is an additional source of $p^{\prime}$-inner $p$-consistent groups:
Example 7.2. Let $L / F$ be a $p^{\prime}$-extension, i.e., a finite separable field extension such that the degree of its normal closure is prime to $p$. Given an inner reductive group $H$ over $F$, the group $G:=R_{L / F}\left(H_{L}\right)$, where $R_{L / F}$ is the Weil transfer, is $p^{\prime}$-inner and $p$-consistent.

The following theorem applies to A-upper motives (as defined in 5.1 and 6.1) of all the groups listed above, and extends [14, Corollary 2.15].
Theorem 7.3. Let $U_{A}(Y)$ (respectively $U_{A^{\prime}}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$ ) be an $A$-upper motive of a $p^{\prime}$-inner $p$ consistent reductive group $G$ (respectively $G^{\prime}$ ) defined over $F$. The motives $U_{A}(Y)$ and $U_{A^{\prime}}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$ are isomorphic in $\mathrm{CM}(F, \mathbb{F})$ if and only if the Artin motives $A$ and $A^{\prime}$ are isomorphic and the varieties $Y^{F}$ and $Y^{\prime F}$ are equivalent $\bmod p$.

Proof. Let $E / F$ (respectively $E^{\prime} / F$ ) be a minimal Galois extension of $F$ over which $G$ (respectively $G^{\prime}$ ) is of inner type. By assumption, $Y$ is a projective $G_{L}$-homogeneous variety over $F$ for some intermediate field $L$ in $E / F, A$ is an indecomposable summand in $M(L)^{F}$ and $U_{A}(Y)$ is an indecomposable summand in $U(Y)^{F}$ with $\mathbf{m}\left(U_{A}(Y)\right)=A$. And similarly for $G^{\prime}, Y^{\prime}, A^{\prime}$ and some intermediate field $L^{\prime}$ in $E^{\prime} / F$, with $\mathbf{m}\left(U_{A^{\prime}}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)\right)=A^{\prime}$. Applying the functor $\mathbf{m}$ to an isomorphism $U_{A}(Y) \simeq U_{A^{\prime}}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$ produces an isomorphism $A \simeq A^{\prime}$. So we may assume $A$ and $A^{\prime}$ are isomorphic.

By (5.15), we have $U_{A}(Y) \simeq U\left(Y^{F}\right) \otimes A$ and $U_{A^{\prime}}\left(Y^{\prime}\right) \simeq U\left(Y^{\prime F}\right) \otimes A^{\prime}$. Hence, if the varieties $Y^{F}$ and $Y^{\prime F}$ are equivalent, so that $U\left(Y^{F}\right) \simeq U\left(Y^{\prime F}\right)$ (see [14, Cor. 2.15]), we get $U_{A}(Y) \simeq U_{A^{\prime}}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$ as expected.

Assume conversely that $U_{A}(Y) \simeq U_{A^{\prime}}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$. Since $G$ is $p$-consistent, there exists a $G$ projective homogeneous variety $\hat{Y}$ over $F$ such that $Y^{F}$ and $\hat{Y}$ are equivalent. The Artin motive $A_{F(\hat{Y})} \simeq A_{F(\hat{Y})}^{\prime}$ is a direct summand in $U_{A}(Y)_{F(\hat{Y})}$, hence also in $U_{A^{\prime}}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)_{F(\hat{Y})}$. By Remark 5.14, this implies that the Tate motive $\mathbb{F}$ is a direct summand in $U\left(Y^{\prime F}\right)_{F(\hat{Y})}$. So, the variety $\left(Y^{\prime F}\right)_{F(\hat{Y})}$ is isotropic (i.e., has a 0 -cycle of degree $1 \in \mathbb{F}$ ), which means that $Y^{F}$ dominates $\hat{Y}$ and $Y^{\prime F}$. The same argument shows that $Y^{\prime F}$ dominates $Y^{F}$ and we conclude that they are equivalent.

We write $R_{L / F}(Y)$ and $R_{L^{\prime} / F}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$ for the $F$-varieties given by the Weil transfers of the $L$-variety $Y$ and the $L^{\prime}$-variety $Y^{\prime}$ respectively. Since the groups $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ are $p^{\prime}$-inner and $p$-consistent, the conditions of Lemma 2.2 apply to $Y$ and $Y^{\prime}$. Therefore, under the conditions of Theorem 7.3, and using the notations introduced in the proof, we get:

Corollary 7.4. The motives $U_{A}(Y)$ and $U_{A^{\prime}}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$ are isomorphic if and only if the Artin motives $A$ and $A^{\prime}$ are isomorphic and the Weil transfers $R_{L / F}(Y)$ and $R_{L^{\prime} / F}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$ are equivalent.

From now on, all the motives considered belong to the full additive subcategory of $\mathrm{CM}(F, \mathbb{F})$ generated by direct summands of Tate shifts of motives of geometrically split varieties satisfying the nilpotence principle. The Krull-Schmidt property holds for all objects in this category by [3, Corollary 35] and [14, Corollary 2.6] (see also [6, Proposition 2.1]), so we may give the following definition:

Definition 7.5. The Artin-Tate trace of a motive $M$ is the part in a complete decomposition of $M$ which consists of Artin-Tate motives. We say that two motives have the same higher Artin-Tate trace if over all field extensions of $F$ their Artin-Tate traces are isomorphic.

We get the following classification theorem, which extends [6, Theorem 4.3].
Theorem 7.6. Let $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ be $F$-motives. We assume that each summand in a complete decomposition of any of them is isomorphic to a Tate shift of an $A$-upper motive of a $p^{\prime}$-inner and $p$-consistent reductive group. The motives $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ are isomorphic if and only if they have the same higher Artin-Tate trace.

Remark 7.7. By Theorem 6.3, this applies to direct sums of shifts of motives of projective homogeneous varieties under $p^{\prime}$-inner and $p$-consistent reductive groups.

Proof of Theorem 7.6. If $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ are isomorphic, then by the Krull-Schmidt property, they have the same higher Artin-Tate trace.

Conversely, assume that $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ have the same higher Artin-Tate trace. We prove that $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ are isomorphic by induction on the maximum of the number of summands in their respective complete motivic decompositions. If this maximum is zero, both $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ are trivial. If it is nonzero, write

$$
M=U_{A_{1}}\left(X_{1}\right)\left\{n_{1}\right\} \oplus . . \oplus U_{A_{k}}\left(X_{k}\right)\left\{n_{k}\right\} \text { and } M^{\prime}=U_{B_{1}}\left(Y_{1}\right)\left\{m_{1}\right\} \oplus \ldots \oplus U_{B_{s}}\left(Y_{s}\right)\left\{m_{s}\right\}
$$

where $A_{i}$ and $B_{j}$ are Artin motives and $X_{i}$ and $Y_{j}$ are corestrictions of projective homogeneous varieties defined over some separable field extensions of $F$. We may assume that $n=\min _{1 \leq i \leq k} n_{i}$ is not higher than $m=\min _{1 \leq j \leq s} m_{j}$. Pick an integer $1 \leq \alpha \leq k$ such that the Weil transfer $R\left(X_{\alpha}\right)$ to $F$ of $X_{\alpha}$ is minimal for the domination relation among the $R\left(X_{i}\right)$ 's such that $U_{A_{i}}\left(X_{i}\right)\{n\}$ is a direct summand in the above decomposition of $M$ (to lighten notation, we write here $R(\cdot)$ for Weil transfers, dismissing the associated finite separable extensions).

Over the function field of $R\left(X_{\alpha}\right)$ the motive $M$ contains as a summand the ArtinTate motive $A\{n\}$ with $A:=\left(A_{\alpha}\right)_{F\left(R\left(X_{\alpha}\right)\right)}$. By assumption on the higher Artin-Tate traces of $M$ and $M^{\prime}$, it follows that the motive $M^{\prime}$ over the same function field also contains $A\{n\}$. Moreover, $A$ is indecomposable by Corollary 3.8. So $A\{n\}$ is a summand in $U_{B_{\beta}}\left(Y_{\beta}\right)\left\{m_{\beta}\right\}_{F\left(R\left(X_{\alpha}\right)\right)}$ for some $1 \leq \beta \leq s$. Hence, we have $m_{\beta}=m=n$ and $U\left(Y_{\beta}^{F}\right)_{F\left(R\left(X_{\alpha}\right)\right)}$ contains a Tate summand $\mathbb{F}$, see Remark 5.14. The variety $R\left(X_{\alpha}\right)$ dominates $R\left(Y_{\beta}\right)$, and $\left(B_{\beta}\right)_{F\left(R\left(X_{\alpha}\right)\right)}$ is isomorphic to $A$. Applying again Corollary 3.8, we get that the Artin motives $A_{\alpha}$ and $B_{\beta}$ are isomorphic.

The same argument over the function field of $R\left(Y_{\beta}\right)$ yields some $1 \leq \gamma \leq k$ such that $R\left(X_{\gamma}\right)$ is dominated by $R\left(Y_{\beta}\right), A_{\gamma} \simeq A_{\alpha}$, and $n_{\gamma}=n$.

By minimality of $R\left(X_{\alpha}\right)$, the varieties $R\left(X_{\alpha}\right), R\left(X_{\gamma}\right)$ and $R\left(Y_{\beta}\right)$ are equivalent. The A-upper motives $U_{A}\left(X_{\alpha}\right)$ and $U_{A}\left(Y_{\beta}\right)$ are then isomorphic by Corollary 7.4. Induction, applied to the complementary summands in $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ of $U_{A}\left(X_{\alpha}\right)\{n\}$ and $U_{A}\left(Y_{\beta}\right)\{n\}$, proves that $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ are isomorphic.

Corollary 7.8. The motives of two projective homogeneous varieties for two absolutely simple groups of type different from ${ }^{3} \mathcal{D}_{4}$ and ${ }^{6} \mathcal{D}_{4}$ are isomorphic if and only if they have the same higher Artin-Tate trace.

Proof. Let $G, G^{\prime}$ be two absolutely simple groups of (possibly different) type not ${ }^{3} \mathcal{D}_{4}$, nor ${ }^{6} \mathcal{D}_{4}$. Assume that $X$ is projective $G$-homogeneous and $Y$ is projective $G^{\prime}$-homogeneous.

If the motives of $X$ and $Y$ have the same higher Artin-Tate trace, then they clearly share the same higher Tate trace as well. The case where both $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ are $p$-inner then boils down to [6, Theorem 4.3].

If $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ are both $p^{\prime}$-inner and $p$-consistent, Theorem 6.3 asserts that both motives $M(X)$ and $M(Y)$ can be written as direct sums of Tate shifts of A-upper motives. We thus land in the conditions of Theorem 7.6.

In the remaining case, one of the group, say $G$, is $p$-inner, while the other, $G^{\prime}$, is $p^{\prime}$-inner and $p$-consistent. For any field extension $E / F$, the Artin-Tate trace of $M\left(Y_{E}\right)$ becomes pure Tate over any prime-to- $p$ field extension over which $G^{\prime}$ is of inner type. Since the Tate trace of $M\left(X_{E}\right)$ is invariant over such an extension by [6, Lemma 5.9], it follows

that if the higher Artin-Tate traces of $M(X)$ and $M(Y)$ are isomorphic, they actually correspond to the higher Tate traces of $M(X)$ and $M(Y)$. Assume an A-upper motive $U_{A}(Z)\{i\} \simeq U(\hat{Z}) \otimes A\{i\}$ is a direct summand of $M(Y)$. Then $M\left(Y_{F(\hat{Z})}\right)$ contains an indecomposable direct summand isomorphic to $A_{F(\hat{Z})}$ (see (5.15) and Corollary 3.8) which must be a Tate motive by the previous discussion. It follows that $A$ is itself a Tate motive, and $M(Y)$ can be written as a direct sum of Tate shifts of upper motives. The motive $M(Y)$ thus fulfills the conditions of [6, Theorem 4.3], as well as $M(X)$.

Remark 7.9. Corollary 7.8 is stated for motives of projective homogeneous varieties, but holds more generally for their arbitrary direct summands (with the same proof).

# 8. Motivic equivalence for reductive Groups 

Motivic equivalence for algebraic groups has been introduced by the first author in [4]. Roughly speaking two inner reductive groups with the same Dynkin diagram are called motivic equivalent if their respective projective homogeneous varieties of any given type have isomorphic motives. This notion can be extended to non-inner reductive groups using corestriction of motives. The main result of this section is Corollary 8.5, which provides a criterion of motivic equivalence for $p^{\prime}$-inner $p$-consistent reductive algebraic groups which are inner forms of each other, in terms of their higher Tits $p$-indexes. Combining this with a similar result for $p$-inner reductive groups proved in [6], we get that the criterion actually holds for all absolutely simple algebraic groups of type other than ${ }^{3} \mathcal{D}_{4}$ and ${ }^{6} \mathcal{D}_{4}$.

We start with a proposition which provides conditions under which we may extend scalars to a function field to detect isomorphim for some A-upper motives.

Proposition 8.1. Let $X$ be a projective homogeneous $F$-variety. Consider two reductive algebraic groups $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ over $F$. Let $L / F$ and $L^{\prime} / F$ be two $p^{\prime}$-extensions (i.e. finite separable field extensions with Galois closure of degree prime to p), and pick some indecomposable summands $A$ in $M(L)^{F}$ and $A^{\prime}$ in $M\left(L^{\prime}\right)^{F}$. Let $Y, Y^{\prime}$ be projective homogeneous varieties over $L$ and $L^{\prime}$ under $G_{L}$ and $G_{L^{\prime}}^{\prime}$, respectively, which are equivalent to the restrictions of some projective homogeneous $F$-varieties. If $Y^{F}$ and $Y^{\prime F}$ both dominate $X$, and if the $A$-upper $F(X)$-motives $U_{A_{F(X)}}\left(Y_{L(X)}\right)$ and $U_{A_{F(X)}^{\prime}}\left(Y_{L^{\prime}(X)}^{\prime}\right)$ are isomorphic, then the $F$-motives $U_{A}(Y)$ and $U_{A^{\prime}}\left(Y^{\prime}\right)$ are isomorphic as well.

Remark 8.2. By Corollary 3.8, $A_{F(X)}$ is an indecomposable summand of $M(L(X))^{F(X)}$, and similarly for $A_{F(X)}^{\prime}$. So the A-upper motives considered in the statement of Proposition 8.1 are well defined, see Notation 5.7.

Proof of Proposition 8.1. Assume that $U_{A_{F(X)}}\left(Y_{L(X)}\right)$ and $U_{A_{F(X)}^{\prime}}\left(Y_{L^{\prime}(X)}^{\prime}\right)$ are isomorphic. By Theorem 7.3, the $F(X)$-motives $A_{F(X)}$ and $A_{F(X)}^{\prime}$ are isomorphic and the $F(X)$ varieties $\left(Y^{F}\right)_{F(X)}$ and $\left(Y^{\prime F}\right)_{F(X)}$ are equivalent. Corollary 3.8 shows that $A \simeq A^{\prime}$, and by [4, Proof of Proposition 9], $Y^{F}$ and $Y^{\prime F}$ are equivalent. The conclusion follows applying again Theorem 7.3.

Given a reductive group $G$ over $F$, we denote by $D_{G}$ its Dynkin diagram, that is the Dynkin diagram of the root system of $G_{\hat{F}}$ with respect to $T_{\hat{F}}$, for some maximal torus $T \subset G$. Sometimes, depending on the context, $D_{G}$ stands for the set of vertices of the

Dynkin diagram. We also denote by $E$ a minimal field extension of $F$ over which $G$ becomes inner, so that the action of $\Gamma_{F}$ on $D_{G}$ (also called the $*$-action) factors through $\operatorname{Gal}(E / F)$.

Any $*$-invariant subset $\tau \subset D_{G}$ yields a projective $G$-homogeneous variety denoted by $X_{G, \tau}$, and this induces a bijection between the $*$-invariant subsets of $D_{G}$ and the isomorphism classes of projective $G$-homogeneous varieties. Note that we use the same convention as in the proof of Theorem 6.3 for this identification; in particular, the empty set corresponds to $\operatorname{Spec} F$.

A vertex of $D_{G}$ is called distinguished if it is contained in an orbit $\tau$ such that the variety $X_{G, \tau}$ has a rational point. The classical Tits index of $G$ consists of its Dynkin diagram $D_{G}$, endowed with the $*$-action, together with the subset $D_{G}^{0} \subset D_{G}$ which consists of all distinguished vertices. In a similar way, a vertex is called $p$-distinguished if it is contained in an orbit $\tau$ such that the variety $X_{G, \tau}$ is isotropic $(\bmod p)$, that is admits a closed point of degree prime to $p$. We denote by $D_{G}^{p}$ the set of all $p$-distinguished vertices, see [5].

In the proofs, we will use the fact that a projective homogeneous variety $X$ is isotropic $(\bmod p)$ if and only if its upper motive is a Tate motive, see [6, Lemma 2.2]. Combining with [14, Corollary 2.15], we get that two equivalent varieties are isotropic over the same extensions of their base field.

Consider now two reductive groups $G$ and $G^{\prime}$. We assume each of them is an inner form of the other, or, equivalently, both are inner forms of the same quasi-split group. In such a situation, the Dynkin diagrams $D_{G}$ and $D_{G^{\prime}}$ are $\Gamma_{F}$-equivariant isomorphic and we will fix one of the possible isomorphisms.
Proposition 8.3. Let $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ be $p^{\prime}$-inner $p$-consistent reductive groups over $F$, inner forms of each other. Fix an equivariant isomorphism $\varphi: D_{G} \rightarrow D_{G^{\prime}}$ of their Dynkin diagrams, and a $*$-invariant subset $\tau_{0}$ of $D_{G}$. Let $E / F$ be a minimal field extension over which $G_{E}$, hence also $G_{E}^{\prime}$, is of inner type. The following conditions on $G, G^{\prime}, \tau_{0}$, and $\varphi$ are equivalent:
(i) for any field extension $K / F$, one has $\tau_{0} \subset D_{G_{K}}^{p}$ (i.e., $\tau_{0}$ is $p$-distinguished over $K$ ) if and only if $\varphi\left(\tau_{0}\right) \subset D_{G_{K}^{\prime}}^{p}$; moreover, for any $K / F$ over which these equivalent conditions hold, we have $\varphi\left(D_{G_{K}}^{p}\right)=D_{G_{K}^{\prime}}^{p}$;
(ii) for any field extension $L / F$ contained in $E$, any indecomposable summand $A$ of the motive $M(L)^{F}$, and any $\operatorname{Gal}(E / L)$-invariant subset $\tau \subset D_{G}$ containing $\tau_{0}$, the $A$-upper motives $U_{A}\left(X_{G_{L}, \tau}\right)$ and $U_{A}\left(X_{G_{L}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}\right)$ are isomorphic.

Proof. Assuming (i), fix a field extension $L / F$ contained in $E$, an Artin motive $A$, and a subset $\tau \supset \tau_{0}$ as in (ii). The subset $\tau_{0}$ is $p$-distinguished for $G$ over the function field $\tilde{L}$ of the variety $X_{G_{L}, \tau}$. Therefore, by condition (i), the subset $\varphi(\tau) \subset D_{G^{\prime}}$ is $p$-distinguished over $\tilde{L}$. The $L$-variety $X_{G_{L}, \tau}$ thus dominates $X_{G_{L}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$. The same reasoning with $\varphi(\tau)$ and the inverse of $\varphi$ implies that the $L$-varieties $X_{G_{L}, \tau}$ and $X_{G_{L}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are equivalent. Hence, the $F$-varieties $X_{G_{L}, \tau}^{F}$ and $X_{G_{L}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}^{F}$ are equivalent (see Remark 2.1), and the A-upper motives $U_{A}\left(X_{G_{L}, \tau}\right)$ and $U_{A}\left(X_{G_{L}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}\right)$ are isomorphic by Theorem 7.3.

Let us now prove the converse. Condition (ii) applied to $L=F$ and $\tau=\tau_{0}$ shows that the upper motives $U\left(X_{G, \tau_{0}}\right)$ and $U\left(X_{G^{\prime}, \varphi\left(\tau_{0}\right)}\right)$ are isomorphic. Therefore, given a field

extension $K / F$, the variety $X_{G_{K}, \tau_{0}}$ is isotropic if and only if $X_{G_{K}^{\prime}, \varphi\left(\tau_{0}\right)}$ is isotropic as well. This means that over the field $K, \tau_{0}$ is $p$-distinguished for $G$ if and only if $\varphi\left(\tau_{0}\right)$ is for $G^{\prime}$.

To prove the second part of (i), let us fix a field extension $K / F$ such that $\tau_{0}$ is $p$ distinguished over $K$, and denote $\Theta=D_{G_{K}}^{p} \subset D_{G}$. By definition of $\Theta$, the $K$-variety $X_{G_{K}, \Theta}$ is isotropic, so there exists a prime-to- $p$ field extension $M / K$ such that $X_{G_{M}, \Theta}$ has a rational point. Let $L / F$ be a minimal subfield of $E$ such that $\Theta$ is $\operatorname{Gal}(E / L)$ invariant. By [15, Theorem 3.16(i)], replacing $E$ by an isomorphic field extension of $F$ if necessary, we may assume $L \subset M$. Condition (ii) applied to $L$ and $\tau=\Theta$ now provides an isomorphism of the A-upper motives $U_{A}\left(X_{G_{L}, \Theta}\right)$ and $U_{A}\left(X_{G_{L}^{\prime}, \varphi(\Theta)}\right)$. Hence, the $L$-varieties $X_{G_{L}, \Theta}$ and $X_{G_{L}^{\prime}, \varphi(\Theta)}$ are equivalent $(\bmod p)$. As $L$ is contained in $M$, it follows that $X_{G_{M}, \Theta}$ and $X_{G_{M}^{\prime}, \varphi(\Theta)}$ also are equivalent. The first one has a rational point, so the second is isotropic; since $[M: K]$ is prime to $p$, it follows that $X_{G_{K}^{\prime}, \varphi(\Theta)}$ also is isotropic.

Thus, the subset $\varphi(\Theta)=\varphi\left(D_{G_{K}}^{p}\right)$ is $p$-distinguished for $G^{\prime}$ over $K$. The same reasoning with $G$ replaced by $G^{\prime}, \tau_{0}$ by $\varphi\left(\tau_{0}\right)$, and $\varphi$ by its inverse, gives that $\varphi^{-1}\left(D_{G_{K}^{\prime}}^{p}\right) \subset D_{G_{K}}^{p}$. Hence $\varphi\left(D_{G_{K}}^{p}\right)=D_{G_{K}^{\prime}}^{p}$.

Consider an arbitrary subset $\tau$ of $D_{G}$. There exists a minimal field extension $L_{\tau} / F$ contained in $E / F$ such that $\tau$ is $\operatorname{Gal}\left(E / L_{\tau}\right)$-invariant. The $F$-motive $M_{G, \tau}:=M\left(X_{G_{L_{\tau}}, \tau}\right)^{F}$ is called the standard motive of $G$ of type $\tau$.

If $\tau$ is $*$-invariant, it is simply the motive of the projective $G$-homogeneous variety $X_{G, \tau}$.
Theorem 8.4. Let $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ be $p^{\prime}$-inner $p$-consistent reductive groups over a field $F$ which are inner forms of each other. Let $\tau_{0}$ be an invariant subset in $D_{G}$. The equivalent conditions of Proposition 8.3 are satisfied if and only if for any subset $\tau \subset D_{G}$ containing $\tau_{0}$, the motives $M_{G, \tau}$ and $M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are isomorphic.
Proof. The "if" part is clear: if the motives $M_{G, \tau}$ and $M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are isomorphic, then for any field $L$ with $L_{\tau} \subset L \subset E$, the varieties $X_{G_{L}, \tau}^{F}$ and $X_{G_{L}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}^{F}$ are equivalent. Hence, by Theorem 7.3, $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ satisfy condition (ii) of Proposition 8.3.

We prove the opposite implication by induction on the (common) semisimple rank of $G$ and $G^{\prime}$. More concretely, assuming the conditions of Proposition 8.3, we will prove that for every $\tau \supset \tau_{0}$ the motives $M_{G, \tau}$ and $M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are isomorphic. For $\tau=\emptyset$ the isomorphism trivially holds. This covers the rank zero case, which is the base of the induction. Below we assume that $\tau \neq \emptyset$.

We first show that $M_{G, \tau}$ and $M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are isomorphic if $\tau$ and $\varphi(\tau)$ are $\operatorname{Gal}(E / F)$ invariant and the associated varieties both have a rational point (hence the reductive algebraic groups $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ are isotropic).

Let $\tilde{G}$ be the semisimple part of a parabolic subgroup in $G$ of type $\tau$. The Dynkin diagram $D_{\tilde{G}}$ of $\tilde{G}$ is obtained by removing the subset $\tau$ from $D_{G}$, and $\tilde{G}_{E}$ is of inner type. By [1, Theorem 4.2], there is a motivic decomposition

$$
M_{G, \tau} \simeq \bigoplus_{i \in \mathcal{I}} M_{\tilde{G}_{L_{i}}, \tau_{i}}^{F}\left\{n_{i}\right\}
$$

with some field extensions $L_{i} / F$ contained in $E$ and some $\operatorname{Gal}\left(E / L_{i}\right)$-invariant $\tau_{i} \subset D_{\tilde{G}}$. Note that the fields $L_{i}$, the projective $\tilde{G}_{L_{i}}$-homogeneous varieties $X_{\tilde{G}_{L_{i}}, \tau_{i}}$, and the shifting

numbers $n_{i}$ in this decomposition are completely determined by the underlying combinatorics of $G$. In particular, the isomorphism $\varphi: D_{G} \rightarrow D_{G^{\prime}}$ from Proposition 8.3 yields an analogous decomposition of $M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ with respect to the semisimple part $\tilde{G}^{\prime}$ of a parabolic subgroup in $G^{\prime}$ of type $\varphi(\tau)$, with the same $\mathcal{I}, L_{i}, \tau_{i}$, and $n_{i}$ :

$$
M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)} \simeq \bigoplus_{i \in \mathcal{I}} M_{\tilde{G}_{L_{i}, \varphi\left(\tau_{i}\right)}}^{F}\left\{n_{i}\right\}
$$

Since $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ are inner forms of each other and satisfy condition (i) of Proposition 8.3 for $\tau_{0} \subset D_{G}$, the groups $\tilde{G}$ and $\tilde{G}^{\prime}$ also do, for $\tilde{\tau}_{0}=\emptyset$. Indeed, since $X_{G, \tau}$ and $X_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are isotropic, for any field extension $K / F$, we have disjoint union decompositions

$$
D_{G_{K}}^{p}=D_{\tilde{G}_{K}}^{p} \sqcup \tau \quad \text { and } \quad D_{G_{K}^{\prime}}^{p}=D_{\tilde{G}_{K}^{\prime}}^{p} \sqcup \varphi(\tau)
$$

Condition (i) of Proposition 8.3 for $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ gives that $D_{G_{K}^{\prime}}^{p}=\varphi\left(D_{G_{K}}^{p}\right)$ and hence $D_{G_{K}}^{p}=\varphi\left(D_{G_{K}}^{p}\right)$. It follows that for any any $i \in \mathcal{I}$ and any field extension $L_{i} / F$, the reductive groups $\tilde{G}_{L_{i}}$ and $\tilde{G}_{L_{i}}^{\epsilon}$ also satisfy condition (i) of Proposition 8.3 with respect to the restriction of $\varphi$ and the subset $\tilde{\tau}_{0}=\emptyset$. By induction, the motives $M_{\tilde{G}_{L_{i}}, \tau_{i}}$ and $M_{\tilde{G}_{L_{i}}^{\prime}, \varphi\left(\tau_{i}\right)}$ are thus isomorphic. Therefore, the motives $M_{\tilde{G}_{L_{i}}, \tau_{i}}^{F}$ and $M_{\tilde{G}_{L_{i}}^{\prime}, \varphi\left(\tau_{i}\right)}^{F}$ are isomorphic as well and so $M_{G, \tau} \simeq M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$.

The second case we consider is that of arbitrary $\operatorname{Gal}(E / F)$-invariant subsets $\tau$ and $\varphi(\tau)$. We will reduce to the previous case using scalar extension to the function field of a variety as in Proposition 8.1. Let us first introduce a set of integers describing motivic decompositions. For any projective $G$-homogeneous variety $X$ and any direct summand $M$ in $M(X)$, we write $\ell_{A, Y, n}(M)$ for the number of indecomposable summands isomorphic to the A-upper summand $U_{A}(Y)\{n\}$ in a complete decomposition of $M$, where $U_{A}(Y)$ is a A-upper motive of $G$, see Definition 6.1 and Theorem 6.3. Since $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ satisfy the conditions of Proposition 8.3, the A-upper motives of $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ are pairwise isomorphic, and we may also consider the number of indecomposable summands isomorphic to $U_{A}(Y)$ in a direct summand of the motive of a $G^{\prime}$-projective homogeneous variety, for which we use a similar notation. If the motives of $X_{G, \tau}$ and $X_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are not isomorphic, then $\ell_{A, Y, n}\left(M_{G, \tau}\right) \neq \ell_{A, Y, n}\left(M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}\right)$ for some A-upper motive $U_{A}(Y)$ of $G$. Consider the minimal integer $n$ for which such a non-equality occurs.

Over the function field $K / F$ of the product $\Pi:=X_{G, \tau} \times X_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ both $X_{G, \tau}$ and $X_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ have a rational point. So $M_{G_{K}, \tau}$ and $M_{G_{K}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are isomorphic. Moreover, the motive $A_{K}$ is indecomposable (see Corollary 3.8) and so we can investigate the integer $\ell_{A_{K}, Y_{K}, n}\left(M_{G_{K}, \tau}\right)$. To lighten notation (by abusing it), below we will write $Y_{K}$ for the variety $Y_{L(\Pi)}$. If $U_{A_{K}}\left(Y_{K}\right)\{n\}$ is a direct summand of $M_{G_{K}, \tau}$, then by the Krull-Schmidt property and Theorem 6.3, it is a direct summand in the $K / F$-restriction $\left(U_{B}(Z)\{k\}\right)_{K}$ of an A-upper motive $U_{B}(Z)$ of $G$, shifted by some integer $k$. By (5.15), we have $\left(U_{B}(Z)\right)_{K} \simeq U_{B_{K}}\left(Z_{K}\right) \oplus$ $N$, where $N$ is a direct sum of A-upper motives with Tate shifts at least 1 ; therefore, $k \leq n$. Since $X_{G, \tau}$ and $X_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are equivalent, any projective homogeneous variety which dominates $X_{G, \tau}$ (or $X_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ ) dominates their product. In particular, Proposition 8.1 implies that a direct summand $U_{A_{K}}\left(Y_{K}\right)\{n\}$ of $M\left(X_{G_{K}, \tau}\right)$ may only arise from a $K / F$ restriction $\left(U_{B}(Z)\{n\}\right)_{K}$ with the same shift $n$ if $B$ and $A$ are isomorphic Artin motives

and $Z$ and $Y$ are equivalent, that is from the A-upper motive $U_{A}(Y)\{n\}$ (see Theorem 7.3).

Write $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ for the direct summands of $M_{G, \tau}$ and $M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$, respectively, given by the sum of all the indecomposable summands isomorphic to A-upper motives of $G$ which shifts strictly lower than $n$ (in a fixed complete decomposition). Thanks to the previous discussion, separating the summands $U_{A_{K}}\left(Y_{K}\right)\{n\}$ of $M_{G_{K}, \tau}$ which arise from $M_{K}$, we get the equalities

$$
\begin{gathered}
\ell_{A_{K}, Y_{K}, n}\left(M_{G_{K}, \tau}\right)=\ell_{A, Y, n}\left(M_{G, \tau}\right)+\ell_{A_{K}, Y_{K}, n}\left(M_{K}\right) \\
\text { and } \ell_{A_{K}, Y_{K}, n}\left(M_{G_{K}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}\right)=\ell_{A, Y, n}\left(M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}\right)+\ell_{A_{K}, Y_{K}, n}\left(M_{K}^{\prime}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

By minimality of $n$, the motives $M$ and $M^{\prime}$ are isomorphic, hence $M_{K}$ and $M_{K}^{\prime}$ are isomorphic as well and $\ell_{A_{K}, Y_{K}, n}\left(M_{K}\right)=\ell_{A_{K}, Y_{K}, n}\left(M_{K}^{\prime}\right)$. As by assumption $\ell_{A, Y, n}\left(M_{G, \tau}\right) \neq$ $\ell_{A, Y, n}\left(M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}\right)$, it follows that $\ell_{A_{K}, Y_{K}, n}\left(M_{G_{K}, \tau}\right)$ and $\ell_{A_{K}, Y_{K}, n}\left(M_{G_{K}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}\right)$ are not equal, a contradiction to the fact that the motives of $X_{G_{K}, \tau}$ and of $X_{G_{K}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are isomorphic (recall that both of these varieties have a rational point).

Finally, consider an arbitrary subset $\tau$ of $D_{G}$. The reductive groups $G_{L_{\tau}}$ and $G_{L_{\tau}}^{\prime}$ satisfy condition (i) of Proposition 8.3. It follows from the Galois-invariant case that the motives $M_{G_{F_{\tau}}, \tau}$ and $M_{G_{F_{\tau}}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}$ are isomorphic, hence so are the motives $M_{G, \tau}=M_{G_{F_{\tau}}, \tau}^{F}$ and $M_{G^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}=M_{G_{F_{\tau}}^{\prime}, \varphi(\tau)}^{F}$, and this finishes the proof.

A field is called $p$-special if every finite extension of this field has a $p$-power degree. Let $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ be two reductive groups, inner forms of each other. Similarly to [4, Definition 1], we say that $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ are motivic equivalent (with coefficients in $\mathbb{F}$ ) with respect to a Galois-equivariant isomorphism $\varphi: D_{G} \rightarrow D_{G^{\prime}}$, if for any subset $\tau$ of $D_{G}$, the motives $M_{\tau, G}$ and $M_{\varphi(\tau), G^{\prime}}$ are isomorphic.

Corollary 8.5. Let $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ be $p^{\prime}$-inner $p$-consistent reductive algebraic groups over $F$, inner forms of each other. Let $\varphi$ be a $*$-equivariant isomorphism of their Dynkin diagrams. The groups $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ are motivic equivalent with respect to $\varphi$ if and only if for any p-special field extension $K / F, \varphi$ identifies the Tits indexes of $G_{K}$ and $G_{K}^{\prime}$.
Proof. Theorem 8.4 with $\tau_{0}=\emptyset$ states that $G$ and $G^{\prime}$ are motivic equivalent with respect to $\varphi$ if and only if for any field extension $K / F, \varphi$ identifies the subsets of $p$-distinguished vertices of $G_{K}$ and $G_{K}^{\prime}$. Over a $p$-special field $K$, this expresses as $\varphi\left(D_{G_{K}}^{0}\right)=D_{G_{K}^{\prime}}^{0}$ (through classical Tits indexes), proving one implication. The converse also holds since a variety is isotropic if and only if it has a rational point over a $p$-special closure of its base field [6, Proof of Lemma 4.11].

abstract:
Given a prime number $p$, we perform the study of Chow motives and motivic
decompositions, with coefficients in $\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$, of projective
homogeneous varieties for $p'$-inner $p$-consistent reductive algebraic groups.
Assorted with the known case of $p$-inner reductive groups, our results cover
all absolutely simple groups of type not $^3\!D_4$ or $^6\!D_4$, among other
examples. First, we define the A-upper motives of such a reductive group $G$;
they are indecomposable motives, naturally related to Artin motives built out
of spectra of subextensions of a minimal extension over which $G$ become of
inner type. With this in hand, we carry on the qualitative study of motivic
decompositions for projective $G$-homogeneous varieties. Providing geometric
isomorphism criteria for A-upper motives, we obtain a classification of motives
of projective $G$-homogeneous varieties, by means of their higher Artin-Tate
traces. We also show that the higher Tits $p$-indexes of the group $G$
determine its motivic equivalence class.
